metadata.synopsis: Innocent young black man Ashtray (Shawn Wayans) is forced to move into a tough Los Angeles slum with his family, including his oddly streetwise, pot-smoking grandma (Helen Martin). Before long, Ashtray's nuclear-armed gangster cousin Loc Dog (Marlon Wayans) introduces him to a bizarrely comic crime underworld. Luckily, Ashtray falls for urban poet Dashiki (Tracey Cherelle Jones), and she convinces him to go straight -- but he must deal with her manic ex-boyfriend Toothpick (Darrel Heath).

reviews: Perhaps if "Menace'' had been shorter and some of the weaker sketches had been left on the cutting-room floor, it would have added up to a stronger whole. In the end, it is too small a menace to match the efforts of filmmakers like Singleton and Lee.
Over-the-top parody has frequent cursing, raunchy humor.
Full of very obvious spoofery, and funnier in concept than in execution.
If you really want to appreciate this film, go see all the hood movies from the 90s - good and bad.
...the Wayans use a sledgehammer to drive in a thumbtack.
There's maybe three or four half-decent chuckles to be found in this otherwise interminable 90-minute mega-chore.
The thin plot is merely the frame for gags, and there are more a few good ones here.
A free-for-all comic spoof that brings the 'hood' genre of Hollywood films full circle.
One of the funniest movies of all time
There are zero laughs in this stupid, stupid movie.
Outrageous is the key word here. In many successful scenes, the Wayans deftly play on our assumptions and cliches.
The gags -- like most of the Wayanses' humor -- range from astute satire to lowest-common-denominator yucks.
